intro: Semecarpus lanceolatus, commonly known as the Indian almond tree, is a deciduous tree native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Sapindaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces smooth, reddish-brown fruits that contain a single seed. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is cultivated in various regions for both aesthetic and practical purposes.
